thread.title: Dems issue warning for budget talks
thread.title_full: Dems issue warning for budget talks

author: dweaver@thehill.com (Mike Lillis)
title: Dems issue warning for budget talks
text:
Dems issue warning for budget talks Greg Nash By Mike Lillis - 10/01/15 06:05 PM EDT 
Democratic leaders in both chambers of Congress, huddling Thursday to plot a budget strategy, emerged with an early warning for Republicans: There will be no deal unless sequestration's spending limits are hiked. 
"We need to stop these devastating sequester cuts from hitting our middle class," Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) said during a press briefing afterwards. "I want to be clear: In the coming weeks, our top priority is lifting the sequester caps." ADVERTISEMENT House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) echoed that message, calling for a budget deal "that grows the economy, that creates jobs, that defends our country." In the Democrats' calculus, that means increasing spending on a long list of government programs.
"We want to remove all doubt in the public's mind that the government will be there, that governance will take place, that the investments that need to be made will be made," Pelosi said. 
Congress on Wednesday passed a short-term spending bill just hours before the government was to close. That legislation provides federal funding — largely at current levels — until Dec. 11, leaving lawmakers with roughly 10 weeks to find a broader agreement extending funding through at least September of next year. 
The comments from Reid and Pelosi foreshadow a tough fight ahead, as Republican leaders consider the across-the-board sequester cuts — enacted as part of the 2011 Budget Control Act — to rank among their top legislative victories under President Obama. 
Excepting for defense spending, which many Republicans want raised, GOP leaders want to keep the sequestration cuts intact in the name of smaller government and deficit reduction. They also face additional pressure from some conservatives to cut even deeper in pursuit of a balanced budget, something that would be a non-starter with Obama and the Democrats. 
Reid said the Democrats huddling Thursday focused on four areas: A top-line budget number to guide the appropriations process; potential offsets that will be needed to lift the sequester caps; how to stave off poison pill "riders" that could sink the package; and their adopted precept that any increase in defense spending has to be matched equally by increases in spending on domestic programs. 
The Democrats declined to weigh in on a timeline governing the negotiations, but emphasized they want to get moving so as not to bump up on the Dec 11 deadline. 
"We don't want to wait," Reid said. 
Reid said he and Pelosi — as well as members of their staffs — have been in close contact with the White House over the party's strategy heading into the high-stakes talks. 
Obama has also been in preliminary discussions with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) in search of an agreement that will prevent a government shutdown in December. 
A wild card in those talks has been Boehner's stunning decision to resign from Congress on Oct. 30. The move has not only created a distraction, as ambitious Republicans fight to work their way up the leadership ladder, but has emboldened the conservatives who toppled the Speaker — a dynamic that could make negotiations much tougher for Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), his likely replacement. 
Asked if it will be more difficult to secure a budget deal under the new Republican leadership, the Democratic leaders declined to offer predictions. 
"We'll see," Pelosi said.
